channel.title: Wes-Anderson on Reviews Per Minute
channel.description: Recent content in Wes-Anderson on Reviews Per Minute

item.title: Poison (2023) - 17 mins
item.description: Deliciously tense and delightfully staged, the uncharacteristically wobbly camerawork and rapid-pace dialogue all build tension so well.

item.title: The Rat Catcher (2023) - 17 mins
item.description: On paper, the most disturbing of these Anderson adaptaions of Dahl but this one didn’t quite click.

item.title: The Swan (2023) - 17 mins
item.description: A wonderful microcosm of Anderson unearthing sincerity from layers of artifice while drawing attention to the artifice.

item.title: The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar (2023) - 42 mins
item.description: A compelling experiment in marrying Anderson and Yeoman’s aesthetic to a straight adaptation although Dahl’s original text contains several Anderson hallmarks: nested structure; quick-wittedness.

item.title: Hotel Chevalier (2007) - 13 mins
item.description: Enigmatically enticing as a little crystallisation of mid-Anderson aesthetic. Would work better standalone.

item.title: The Darjeeling Limited (2007) - 92 mins
item.description: It’s easy to read THE DARJEELING LIMITED as self-indulgent: three wealthy white American men searching for a spiritual experience in a culture with which they make no effort to engage.

item.title: The Royal Tenenbaums (2001) - 110 mins
item.description: I went into this rewatch thinking that this might drop in my Wes Anderson ranking. If anything, I’m considering moving it higher.

item.title: Fantastic Mr. Fox (2009) - 87 mins
item.description: Until the film’s final scene, I would have said that this is, surprisingly, Wes Anderson’s most anti-capitalist film: the contrast between the coldly metallic heavy industrialisation of Boggis, Bunce, and Bean’s farms and the warm autumnal palette of the animals’ home; Mr.

item.title: The French Dispatch (2021) - 108 mins
item.description: I remembered this as the slightest of Wes Anderson’s live-action scripts with Roman Coppola, most notable for the extreme precision of the film’s Andersonian clockwork diorama world and evocativeness of music and visuals.

item.title: Bottle Rocket (1996) - 91 mins
item.description: Like the main characters, this film has a charm and a sincerity that are both beguiling even while it settles into a diffuseness that feels a little frustrating.

item.title: Bottle Rocket (1994) - 14 mins
item.description: This short’s conciseness and energy work better to convey the themes than the feature.

item.title: Moonrise Kingdom (2012) - 94 mins
item.description: In an essay for the Criterion Collection Blu-ray, Isabel Folger writes that “Moonrise Kingdom shows that with the right people in your life, you won’t feel misunderstood.

item.title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004) - 119 mins
item.description: The Titan submersible incident prompted a response by James Cameron highlighting his approach to underwater exploration. I’m struck by the contrast between Wes Anderson’s almost childlike reverence for undersea explorers in the outdated model of Jacques Costeau, expressed in THE LIFE AQUATIC and RUSHMORE, and Cameron’s much more masculine-coded urge to conquer the depths harnessing advanced technology for his pursuit.

item.title: Asteroid City (2023) - 105 mins
item.description: ASTEROID CITY serves as something of an artistic statement for this period of Wes Anderson’s filmmaking, overtly discussing existential themes around meaning and, in particular, finding meaning through art that emphasise Anderson’s complicating of modernism and postmodernism.

item.title: Rushmore (1998) - 93 mins
item.description: Quite apart from the blossoming of his distinctive aesthetic (developed in collaboration with his long-time cinematographer Robert Yeoman who rarely gets enough credit for it), RUSHMORE provides early insights into many of the deeper themes and preoccupations that would go on to define Wes Anderson’s work: a focus on class and social status particularly with regards to the hierarchy of positions within esoteric institutions; an eye for the outsider figure and the social outcast; a fascination with under the sea and the life aquatic.
